column4: I just booted up my computer with that LiveCD, and the Verify CD option found no errors. Does anybody know why this is working on one computer but not another?

Does the LiveCD require a minimum amount of RAM (I'm using the 8.10 desktop version, if that makes a difference)? I'm asking because I just removed a faulty RAM module from the laptop that won't work with the LiveCD.
Have you run memtest on your RAM that's left in?
no, I can't get the RAM test to work. The LiveCD just freezes.
hate to ask... You tried a floppy?
no, this computer doesn't have floppy support. I tried a CD.
hmmm, no idea, I'm willing to suspect that when it tries to load the CD into RAM it has issues and hence the issue
like too little RAM, perhaps? (Not sure if you saw my earlier message or not, but I just finished removing a faulty RAM module from the computer - it only has one RAM module left)
how much is in there? How do you know it was that module that was faulty and not the other?

when I tried booting into Windows, I got a BSOD due to RAM issues, then all kinds of weirdness on the screen, so I figured it had to be a RAM issue. I removed one module and tried booting up with the other and got the same issue; I replaced the second module and pulled out the first, and the system is working better now.
There could still be issues on that other module, do you have any known good?
no, I don't have any modules that are proven OK, but the total absence of BSODs & screen weirdness since I removed the one module is just about enough to convince me
not instantly. I can get to the Ubuntu menu, but as soon as I select an option everything hangs, then the system shuts down about 5 minutes later
OK, could be other issues with the HW elsewhere
wouldn't surprise me. This machine apparently has a long history of trouble.
place on floor, put C4 on top, walk away quickly, detonate C4
